blocks.text: Physical location plays a major role in resilience. Data centers and network facilities must be protected from environmental risks such as flooding, earthquakes, fires, and extreme temperatures.
Geographic diversity reduces the risk that a single regional disaster will disrupt all operations. Organizations often deploy systems across multiple facilities or cloud regions to isolate failures.
Network connectivity between sites must support failover traffic without introducing excessive latency. Bandwidth and routing design directly affect recovery performance.

Physical security is also critical. Unauthorized access to facilities can lead to sabotage, theft, or data destruction. Access controls, surveillance, and environmental monitoring contribute to site resilience.

Site planning must also consider utility dependencies such as power, cooling, and telecommunications. Failure of these supporting services can disrupt operations even if computing systems remain functional.
